messageBody:
> DBC is not about testing. Not even Mr. Bertrand Meyer (the inventor
> of DBC) claims that. If you wanted to test correctnes of
> implementatio with DBC you would have to duplicate a function's
> algorithm - or an equivalent one - in its postcondition. Tests
don't
> suffer from that dilemma since tests can work with samples.

> DBC is not about compile time verification but about runtime
checks.
> Code verification has some relationship to DBC but is a different
> field of research.

> No, that's not what happens when using DBC.

I don't care if the original DBC was not designed to do that. But it
CAN be modified to do what I want to be done with DBC. As you said,
code verification has relationship with DBC.

Lets not call it DBC, call it XXX if you want.

There is a way to use preconditions, postconditions and invariants to
replace at least most JUnit tests.

XXX can be used to create test data at compile time for each method.
Any test data can be used randomly for that purpose as long as it
obeys the precondition. The result of the method can be automatically
compared at compile time with the postcondition. Invariants never may
be violated.

That is all done at *compile time*. My XXX has nothing to do with
checking at run time but with checking at compile time.

Many nice things can done with XXX. For example "Liskovsches
Substitutionsprinzip" can be checked very natively with using XXX
instead of JUnit. This is just one benefit of many using XXX.
